utterances: So you do not have to look for fish, you just look for the conditions the fish like, and you can see that from the satellite?
That's correct.
The fish actually make us look good because they follow those patterns pretty constantly.
Mitchell Roffer runs a fishing forecasting service in West Melbourne, Florida.
Mr. Roffer, thank you for being with us.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
Good morning.
I'm Rachel Martin.
If you're the 32nd-ranked golfer in the world and you make a hole-in-one at the Masters, it's a big deal.
That's what happened at the Par 3 Contest the other day.
And Tony Finau was psyched.
He started jumping up and down to celebrate.
Then, his ankle buckled, and he collapsed on the green.
Then, Finau put his hands on the protruding ankle and appeared to pop the thing back into place.
The golfer says he'll be back on the green today, maybe opting for a simple fist pump next time he makes a good shot.
In the world of science, some tiny clusters of living human brain cells are raising big ethical questions.
They're sometimes called minibrains.
And as NPR's Jon Hamilton reports, they're allowing scientists to mimic aspects of the human brain in a Petri dish.
In the lab, these minibrains still don't get much larger than a pea, and they contain only a few million cells.
The human brain has about 85 billion.
But Nita Farahany of Duke University says these bits of living tissue develop and get wired up a lot like actual brains.
And she says they are helping scientists do remarkable things.

So if you're talking about something like schizophrenia or autism, if you want to model those things, it's difficult to do so with animal models, and it is ethically impossible to do so in many instances with living humans.
But Behravesh says it will be important to structure the plan the right way.
The last time around, a lot of tax payers reportedly used their rebate checks to pay debt, instead of spending them.
And when enough people do that, it can limit the effectiveness of the stimulus plan.
He says a new plan should be designed to encourage spending.

Whatever gets decided, Wall Street seemed to like the idea of a second stimulus plan, stock prices rose sharply early in the day, but went up even more after Bernanke spoke, and the market finished the day much higher.
Jim Zarroli, NPR News.
Back to last night's Obama speech for a moment.
The Democratic candidate talked about taxes and about what he would do...
Listen now, I will cut taxes.
Cut taxes for 95 percent of all working families...
(Soundbite of cheering)
...because in an economy like this, the last thing we should do is raise taxes on the middle class.
Also about what he said John McCain would do or would not do.
...hundreds of billions in tax breaks for big corporations and oil companies, but not one penny of tax relief to more than 100 million Americans.
Well, just in case you weren't watching with a tax accountant, a demographer or an economist, we thought that we'd sort through some of those numbers.
And we've called upon Len Burman, director of the non-partisan Tax Policy Center, which has studied the candidates' tax plans.
Welcome back.
Happy to be here.
Barack Obama said he would not raise taxes on 95 percent of working families.
Who are the other five percent?
How much do you have to make to be part of the five percent?
Basically, it's people in the top two tax brackets.
For a couple, it's income over about $200,000.
For a single family, it's about $165,000 of taxable income.
So, that's before deductions.
He was talking about the federal income tax when he said that.
But he's also talked elsewhere about Social Security tax.
Yeah.
Actually, he's proposed to extend - not entirely clear what the tax would be, but a tax on people with incomes over $250,000 to help bolster Social Security.
Part of it would be paid by individuals, and part paid by companies.
And the only thing he's been specific about is that the combined rate wouldn't be more than about four percent.
But that would apply to very, very high income households.
According to Barack Obama last night, John McCain, he said, would give no tax relief to more than 100 million Americans.
Does that seem accurate to you?
Not according to our estimates.
I mean, there are a couple of ways in which Senator McCain's plans have fairly broad benefits.
One is he cuts the corporate tax, which Senator Obama characterizes as something for corporate fat cats.
But basically anybody who owns stock or, you know, money in the bank is likely to get a higher rate of return if corporations pay less tax.
Second, Senator McCain would extend all the tax cuts that expire at the end of 2010.
And those include provisions that affect low and middle income families as well as those with very high incomes.
And Obama on the tax cuts that expire at the end of 2010?
He would extend almost all of them.
He'd extend the tax cuts that apply to low and middle income households, up to the top two brackets.
For those families he would actually restore taxes to what they were before 2001.
You've spoken of middle-income taxpayers.
Senator Obama spoke of taxes on the middle class.
Is it understood, is there some common definition among people who do tax policy as to what the middle class is or what middle-income tax earners are?
Not really.
I mean, you can look at the statistics and say that a middle income household is somebody earning, you know, between the second fifth and the top fifth of the income distribution.
That would be income of between $19,000 and $111,000.
That would leave out the fifth lowest incomes and the fifth highest incomes; you'd get middle income that way.
Yeah.
I mean, actually the campaigns seem to be taking a much more expansive view of middle class.
Clearly, Senator Obama is talking about people with incomes under a quarter-million dollars.

In some ways, that's consistent with what you get from surveys, because if you interview people, 95 percent of Americans say that they're middle class, including some who are objectively quite poor and some who are quite well-off.
The Obama campaign has been very critical of John McCain for saying that rich starts at an annual income of about $5 million a year.
How many Americans make $5 million a year?
It's a tiny fraction, probably about one-tenth of one percent.
So that would mean that nearly everyone is middle class, in that case, if that's where middle class ends and rich begins.
Senator McCain has a very inclusive definition of middle class.
Len Burman, thank you very much for talking with us today.
My pleasure.
Len Burman is director of the nonpartisan Washington-based Tax Policy Center, which has studied the tax proposals of both Senator Obama and Senator McCain.
And in the U.S., some home sellers in this tough market are getting creative.
Houses built by famous architects are being picked up by auction houses and sold like art.
For example, this past Sunday, a house designed by the late Louis Kahn went on the auction block, but it failed to sell.
Alex Schmidt of member station WHYY has this story on a trend that may or may not help at least one sector of the housing market.
I hear my grandmother, my mother: is good for your blood pressure and good for your stomach, you know.
The play of light is the most essential element to me.
I mean, in this room you really feel it the most, the presence of nature, but then the way light moves through the space throughout the day.
If Wright sounds more like an art dealer than a real estate agent, that's because he's trying to take houses and turn them into collectibles.
Wright isn't the first one to try this.
Sotheby's sold Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House in Illinois five years ago.
And earlier this month, Christie's sold Richard Neutra's Kauffman House in Palm Springs as part of an art auction.
But only a handful of homes have sold this way.
I'm not entirely convinced that architecture is collectible.
Felix Salmon is a blogger for Portfolio.com.
He believes the nature of architecture and auction work against what Richard Wright is trying to do.
Art you can fit into your lifestyle.
With architecture, it's the other way around.
You have to physically move into someone else's vision and someone else's place.

And the chances are is there's really only going to be one or possibly two buyers who love the architecture, are willing to live in the location, have the amount of money available right now to buy it.
And yet, auctioneer Richard Wright has sold two other historic properties for more than he estimated they would bring in.
He was hoping the Esherick House would fetch two to three million.
And he says he had some interest, but no actual bidders.
Christopher Plant, an agent with Philadelphia's Elfant Wissahickon Realtors, says he's not surprised.
Two to three million is an enormous amount of money.
And generally, it comes with a lot more land and it comes with a bigger physical structure.
And most people would want more for the money.
More, that is, than the theoretical and functional experiment that architect Louis Kahn envisioned.
The house was conceived as a home for one person.
It's 2,500 square feet, has one bedroom, one bath, a tiny kitchen, and let's just say the appliances aren't Energy Star certified.
Given the dimensions and age, preservation is an issue.
Anyone paying around a million dollars is probably not going to feel too bad about making a change here or there.
